Manuscript transparency
Your analysis of your study is finally complete. You are ready to upload your manuscript, but you must decide how much of your secret sauce â€“ the raw data files, the proprietary metadata, and your specific coding scheme - you will attach to the public repository.






ImportantThe Transparency Advocate





You upload everything to a public repository with a DOI. Every step of your method is visible and reproducible. Itâ€™s exhausting work that eats into your research time, but you are a paragon of Open Science.

TipThe Strategic Gatekeeper





You share a summary dataset and your final results, but you keep the raw data and the specifics private. It protects your competitive advantage for future papers and keeps your reputation high among peers who value proprietary data, though Open Science advocates find it lacking.

-4 ğ”ˆ, -2 â„œ, +3 ğ”

title: Open science publishing game
text:
Journal choices







ImportantğŸ’  Diamond Open Access





Diamond OA provides immediate free access to articles without charging article processing charges (APCs) to authors. Journals are supported by institutions, scholarly societies, grants, consortia, or volunteer labor. Articles are often published under open licenses (e.g., CC BY), enabling reuse and broad dissemination.

advantage: equitable for both authors and readers, freely accessible to anyone
drawback: sustainability depends on external funding or unpaid labor










ImportantğŸ¥‡ Gold Open Access





Gold OA makes the final published article immediately free on the publisherâ€™s site. Funding commonly comes from article processing charges (APCs) paid by authors, institutions, or funders. Articles are often published under open licenses (e.g., CC BY), enabling reuse and broad dissemination.

advantage: maximum visibility and compliance with OA mandates, freely accessible to anyone
drawback: APCs can exclude authors without funding










ImportantğŸ“” Conventional publishing (â€œclosedâ€ access)





Conventional â€œclosedâ€ journals restrict access to subscribers or pay-per-view users. Publishers generate revenue only from individual or institutional subscriptions because authors typically do not pay publication fees. Content is usually under publisher-controlled licenses, limiting reuse and redistribution.

advantage: you get to (in many fields still) the best-known and widest reaching journals
drawback: limited readership and barriers to access










Importantâ‰ï¸ Predatory journals





Predatory journals publish the article immediately without any direct peer review. The author is charged lower publication fees, but the editors provide little or no quality control, archiving or indexing.

advantage: fast processing and easy acceptance, (may be) freely accessible to anyone
drawback: low quality assurance, risk to author reputation and career, higher costs and lack of transparency

title: About
text:
This game was a collaboration of Philip, Ceren, Matteo and Nelly as a group project for the class â€œOpen Science practices in applied linguistics and second language acquisitionâ€ by Elen Le Foll.
The main objective of this game is to have players gain insides into both academic work and open access publishing. It leads the players through a series of decisions, highlighting the trade-offs between Money, Ethics and Reputation in academic publishing.
The ultimate goal of this game is not winning. We invite the players to have discussions about open science, the way scientific publishing is shaped currently and reflect on their own academic values.
